page.title: 04FARMING PROBLEMS.
page.content: The problems faced by the farmers of the area are caused mostly by wildlife.There is a large population of rabbits which eat young vegetable crops.The two main types of birds that are troublesome are crows and pigeons.Both types excrete on crops, preventing the farmer from selling them.Pigeons also eat young cabbages, as do pheasants. The farmers on the Isle of Wight spend much energy on solving these problems.Rabbits are shot and trapped to prevent them from breeding.Birds are discouraged by the use of scarecrows,bright ribbons and dead birds.At{DUNSBURY FARM}a bird-scaring "cannon" has also been employed.In Winter,there are also expeditions by local farmers into the countryside. These shooting parties kill for sport and as a preventative measure.
